document_title: Mastitis: Causes, signs, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
When symptoms appear: breast pain, nipple discharge, worsening sensation after 24 hours of taking antibiotics or a few days of self-treatment at home, you should see a doctor. [ten]
1. What can you prepare?
Write down your symptoms, including any that seem unrelated to the reason for your appointment.; Make a list of all the medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.; Write down important medical information, including other diseases.; Write down important personal information, including any recent changes or stressors in your life.; Write down questions to ask your doctor. Here are suggested questions to ask your doctor: Will my mastitis go away on its own or do I need treatment? What can I do at home to reduce my symptoms? How can my condition affect my baby? If I continue to breastfeed, is the medication my doctor prescribes safe for my baby? How long will I have to take the medicine? What risk factors can cause the infection to recur? How to reduce the risk of recurrence? In addition to the questions you have prepared to ask your doctor, don't hesitate to ask other questions that come up during your appointment.; Will my mastitis go away on its own or do I need treatment?; What can I do at home to relieve my symptoms?; How may my condition affect my baby?; If I continue to breastfeed, is the medicine my doctor prescribes safe for my baby?; How long will I have to take the medicine?; What risk factors can cause the infection to recur? How to reduce the risk of recurrence?; In addition to the questions you've prepared to ask your doctor, don't hesitate to ask other questions that come up during your appointment.
2. What will the doctor ask?
Your doctor may ask you some questions. Having your answers ready can help you save time for the things you want to spend more time on. You may be asked:
How long have you had the signs and symptoms? Are they in one or both breasts?; How severe is your pain?; In what position do you breastfeed your baby?; Have you ever had mastitis before?
In short, mastitis is not the cause of breast cancer but causes pain and exhaustion for breastfeeding mothers. This condition is also easily confused with inflammatory breast cancer. Therefore, when suffering from mastitis, the patient should see a doctor for examination, treatment, and determination of whether it is breast cancer or not.
The Department of Breast Surgery masters the most advanced techniques with the support of modern machinery and imaging diagnostic equipment systems such as: Mammomat Inspiration 3D digital mammography (DBT) system; GE Logiq E10S ultrasound machine, with probe that supports breast elastography, microvascular survey and biopsy orientation support under ultrasound; The new generation Magnetom Amira BioMatrix 3-tesla MRI machine... will help detect early and have safe and effective treatment plans for diseases related to the mammary gland.
In addition, at Tam Anh General Hospital there is close coordination between specialties such as: Diagnostic Imaging, Laboratory Testing, Obstetrics and Gynecology, Endocrinology, Anesthesiology, Nutrition, Psychology, Physics therapy... helps make treatment planning for patients comprehensive, multi-modal and individualized to shorten time and increase treatment effectiveness.
To schedule an appointment for mastitis examination and treatment with leading experts at the Department of Breast Surgery, Tam Anh General Hospital, please contact:
Mastitis causes pain and discomfort, but with proper home care, it will go away on its own. When the condition does not improve, even pain, causing fever... you should be examined at a general hospital for proper and effective treatment coordination. When her health improves and her spirit is comfortable, the mother will take better care of her child.
